com.milk.objed
Class MethodValueEditor

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.milk.objed.BaseEditor
        |
        +--com.milk.objed.MethodValueEditor
All Implemented Interfaces:
Editable, Editor, ValueEditor
public final class MethodValueEditor
extends BaseEditor
implements ValueEditor

This is a ValueEditor which uses reflection to access a getter and setter method which collectively act like a field on a given target.

Author:
Dan Bornstein, danfuzz@milk.com
, Copyright 1999 Dan Bornstein, all rights reserved.

Constructor Detail

MethodValueEditor

public MethodValueEditor(java.lang.String label,
                         java.lang.String description,
                         java.lang.Object target,
                         java.lang.String name)
Construct a MethodValueEditor to access the given named methods of the given object. The methods are named in the standard way, that is, by prepending "get" or "set" and capitalizing the first letter of the given name. If the set variant doesn't exist, then the "field" is assumed to be immutable. Note that the getter method gets invoked during the creation of this object. Also note that if there are multiple methods of the right names which match the form factors for getter or setter methods, this class will likely get very confused. In such cases, one should use the constructor which explicitly takes Method objects.

Parameters:
label - the label
description - the description
target - the object to access
name - the base name of the methods
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the target doesn't have at least a public getter method with appropriate names

MethodValueEditor

private MethodValueEditor(java.lang.String label,
                          java.lang.String description,
                          java.lang.Object target,
                          java.lang.reflect.Method[] methods)
Constructor that takes the getter and setter as an array, just a convenience to make the code a little prettier. It would have been nice to just use a local variable in the name-based constructor, but it would have had to been done before the call to this(), and Java doesn't allow that. Java just sucks that way sometimes.

Parameters:
label - the label
description - the description
target - the object to access
methods - the array of two methods, a getter and a setter

MethodValueEditor

public MethodValueEditor(java.lang.String label,
                         java.lang.String description,
                         java.lang.Object target,
                         java.lang.reflect.Method getter,
                         java.lang.reflect.Method setter)
Construct a MethodValueEditor to access the explicitly given getter and setter methods of the given object. If the setter is passed as null, it is taken to mean that the field is immutable. Note that the getter method gets invoked during the creation of this object.

Parameters:
label - the label
description - the description
target - the object to access
getter - non-null; the getter method
setter - null-ok; the setter method
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if the getter or doesn't seem to respond properly or if the setter's form factor isn't right (e.g., it either takes more than one argument or it returns void)

public java.lang.Object getValue()
                          throws BadValueException
Get the value from the target.

Specified by:
getValue in interface ValueEditor
Returns:

setValue

public void setValue(java.lang.Object value)
              throws BadValueException,
                     ImmutableException
Set the value in the target.

Specified by:
setValue in interface ValueEditor
Parameters:
value - the new value
Throws:
BadValueException - thrown if the value is inappropriate for this editor
ImmutableException - thrown if the editor is in fact immutable

update

public void update()
Ask this editor to update its internal state. In this case, it does a getValue(), which may in fact cause a valueChanged event to get sent.

Specified by:
update in interface Editor
Specified by:
update in class BaseEditor

findMethods

private static java.lang.reflect.Method[] findMethods(java.lang.Object target,
                                                      java.lang.String name)
Given an object and a base method name, return the Method objects for accessing that "field" on the given object, or throw an IllegalArgumentException (a nice RuntimeException--down with compiler-enforced exception checking!) if there's a problem with the name.

Parameters:
target - the object to access
name - the base name
Returns:
the array of { getter, setter }
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown if there's a problem finding the methods

throwIllegal

private static void throwIllegal(java.lang.Object target,
                                 java.lang.String kind,
                                 java.lang.String name)
Throw and IllegalArgumentException about the given target and method not matching.

Parameters:
target - the object to access
kind - the kind of method (getter or setter)
name - the name of the method
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - thrown by definition
